qas.question: What kind of symmetry do annelids have?
What do annelids use to move?
Which subtype of annelids includes most marine worms?
Which subtype of annelids includes earthworms?
Since 1997, what are leeches seen as a subgroup of?
What kind of symmetry do annelids lack?
What do annelids use to fly?
Which subtype of annelids includes most space worms?
Which subtype of annelids includes marsworms?
What are leeches seen as a subgroup of since 1897?

context: The annelids are <a0_0><b5_0>bilateral<b5_0/><a0_0/>ly symmetrical, triploblastic, coelomate, invertebrate organisms. They also have <a1_0><b6_0>parapodia<b6_0/><a1_0/> for locomotion. Most textbooks still use the traditional division into <a2_0><b7_0>polychaetes<b7_0/><a2_0/> (almost all marine), <a3_0><b9_0>oligochaetes<b9_0/><a3_0/> (which include earthworms) and leech-like species. Cladistic research since 1997 has radically changed this scheme, viewing leeches as a sub-group of <a4_0>oligochaetes<a4_0/> and <b8_0>oligochaetes<b8_0/> as a sub-group of polychaetes. In addition, the Pogonophora, Echiura and Sipuncula, previously regarded as separate phyla, are now regarded as sub-groups of polychaetes. Annelids are considered members of the Lophotrochozoa, a "super-phylum" of protostomes that also includes molluscs, brachiopods, flatworms and nemerteans.
